Benton County Processing

9806 Highway 59

Gentry, AR 72734



RE: Executive Summary, (RMP)



1.ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES.



At Simmons Foods, Inc. we utilize anhydrous ammonia which is considered hazardous by the

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The properties which make ammonia valuable as a

refrigerant also necessitate certain safety precautions. Simmons Foods, Inc. strives to protect all its

valuable resources and assets, both personnel and property. We live and have families in this

community. We want to prevent exposure to all our personnel as well as nearby members of our

community, existing natural resources, and the surrounding environment. It is our policy to comply

with all Federal, State, and local regulations. Through continual, accurate training and various safety

devices and procedures, we work to minimize potential releases.



Our emergency response program has specific procedures for accidental releases of anhydrous

ammonia as well as other emergencies. We work in conjunction with the Gentry Fire Department

and the Local Emergency Planning Committee to prepare for necessary notification of all affected

neighbors.



2.THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.



The primary purpose of our facility is the processing of poultry products. We utilize anhydrous

ammonia as the primary means for refrigeration, cooling and freezing. An outside company is used

to fill our main receiver tanks. Piping then carries the ammonia to the needed refrigeration, cooling

or freezing units. Access to the site is restricted to facility employees, authorized management

personnel and authorized contractors.



3.THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE CASE RELEASE SCENARIO



This location has prepared a worst case release and an alternate case release scenario by using the

RMPComp air dispersion modeling software and MARPLOT for mapping the distance to the toxic

end point and understanding the number of persons affect

ed.



Documentation of these scenarios is kept of file for review upon request.



4.FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.



This is the first time RMP submission for a new facility. No incidents have occurred.



5.THE RMP MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.



The management of the RMP program will be handled by Jeff Norman, Sr. Director of Operations.

Jeff Norman will administrate in conjunction with the Simmons Foods, Inc. management and

personnel. Other entities or organizations that will be coordinated with include the Benton County

LEPC and the Gentry Fire Department and Hazardous Materials Response Team.



6.THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC

PREVENTION STEPS.



In accordance with RMP regulations, the general accidental release prevention program for this

facility's ammonia refrigeration system is comprised of the following components: process safety

information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, operator training, procedures for

maintaining mechanical integrity, procedures for managing system changes, pre-start up safety

review procedures, procedures for investigating release incidents, and hot work permit protocols.

This program was developed with the participation of the affected employees, and will be periodically

audited for compliance required by the RMP regulations. In addition, the facility has in place

procedures for notifying contractors and their employee of the hazards of the system. Chemical

specific prevention steps are included within the program, including engineering and administration

controls designed to prevent and minimize accidental releases.





7.EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.



Simmons Foods, Inc. emergency response program is based on the OSHA requirements for

Emergency Action Plans (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119) and Hazwoper (29 CFR 1910.120). We

have trained employees for emergency response and maintain a written emergency response plan.

This plan is coordinated with the Benton County LEPC, and

Gentry Fire Department. We conduct

drills for implementation of the emergency response plan.
